statements.name: PROC VARCLUS
statements.description: The VARCLUS procedure divides a set of numeric variables into disjoint or hierarchical clusters.

arguments.name: CENTROID
arguments.description: Uses centroid components rather than principal components.

arguments.name: CORR
arguments.description: Displays the correlation matrix.

arguments.name: COVARIANCE
arguments.description: Analyzes the covariance matrix instead of the correlation matrix.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: Specifies the SAS data set to be analyzed.

arguments.name: HIERARCHY
arguments.description: Requires the clusters at different levels to maintain a hierarchical structure. To draw a tree diagram, use the OUTTREE= option and the TREE procedure.

arguments.name: INITIAL=
arguments.description: Specifies the method for initializing the clusters.

arguments.name: GROUP
arguments.description: Obtains the cluster membership of each variable from an observation in the DATA= data set where the _TYPE_ variable has a value of 'GROUP'.

arguments.name: INPUT
arguments.description: Obtains scoring coefficients for the cluster components from observations in the DATA= data set where the _TYPE_ variable has a value of 'SCORE'.

arguments.name: RANDOM
arguments.description: Assigns variables randomly to clusters.

arguments.name: SEED
arguments.description: Initializes each cluster component to be one of the variables named in the SEED statement.

arguments.name: MAXCLUSTERS=
arguments.description: Specifies the largest number of clusters desired. The default value is the number of variables.

arguments.name: MAXEIGEN=
arguments.description: Specifies that when choosing a cluster to split, VARCLUS should choose the cluster with the largest second eigenvalue, provided that its second eigenvalue is greater than the MAXEIGEN= value.

arguments.name: MAXITER=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of iterations during the NCS phase. The default value is 1 if you specify the CENTROID option; the default is 10 otherwise.

arguments.name: MAXSEARCH=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of iterations during the search phase. The default is 1000 divide by the number of variables.

arguments.name: MINCLUSTERS=
arguments.description: Specifies the smallest number of clusters desired. The default value is 2 for INITIAL=RANDOM or INITIAL=SEED; otherwise, VARCLUS begins with one cluster and tries to split it in accordance with the PROPORTION= and/or MAXEIGEN= options.

arguments.name: MULTIPLEGROUP
arguments.description: Performs a multiple group component analysis.

arguments.name: NOINT
arguments.description: Requests that no intercept be used; covariances or correlations are not corrected for the mean.

arguments.name: NOPRINT
arguments.description: Suppresses displayed output. Note that this option temporarily disables the Output Delivery System (ODS).

arguments.name: OUTSTAT=
arguments.description: Creates an output data set to contain statistics including means, standard deviations, correlations, cluster scoring coefficients, and the cluster structure.

arguments.name: OUTTREE=
arguments.description: Creates an output data set to contain information on the tree structure that can be used by the TREE procedure to display a tree diagram.

arguments.name: PLOTS=
arguments.description: Syntax: PLOTS <(global-plot-options)> <= plot-request > PLOTS <(global-plot-options)> <= (plot-request <... plot-request >)> Controls the plots produced through ODS Graphics.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Produces all plots, which for PROC VARCLUS is only a dendrogram.

arguments.name: MAXPOINTS=
arguments.description: Syntax: MAXPOINTS=n | MAXPTS=n Suppresses the dendrogram when the number of variables (clusters) exceeds the n value. This prevents an unreadable plot from being produced. The default is MAXPOINTS=200.

arguments.name: DENDROGRAM
arguments.description: Syntax: DENDROGRAM <( dendrogram-options )> Requests a dendrogram and specifies dendrogram-options. Unlike most graphs, the size of the dendrogram can vary as a function of the number of objects that appear in the dendrogram. You can specify the following dendrogram-options to control the size and appearance of the dendrogram: COMPUTEHEIGHT=a b |CH=a b specifies the constants for computing the height of the dendrogram. For n points being clustered, intercept a, and slope b, the height is based in part on a + bn. For a horizontal dendrogram, the default (given in pixels) is COMPUTEHEIGHT=100 12, the default height in pixels is max(100 + 12n, 480), the default height in inches is max(1.04167 + 0.125n, 5), and the default height in centimeters is max(2.64583 + 0.3175n, 12.7). For a vertical dendrogram, the default height is 480 pixels. The default unit is pixels, and you can use the UNIT= dendrogram-option to change the unit to inches or centimeters for this option. Inches equals pixels divided by 96, and centimeters equals inches times 2.54. COMPUTEWIDTH=a b |CW=a b specifies the constants for computing the width of the dendrogram. For n points being clustered, intercept a, and slope b, the width is based in part on . For a vertical dendrogram, the default (given in pixels) is COMPUTEWIDTH=100 12, the default width in pixels is max(100 + 12n, 640), the default width in inches is max(1.04167 + 0.125n, 6.66667), and the default width in centimeters is max(2.64583 + 0.3175n, 16.933). For a horizontal dendrogram, the default width is 640 pixels. The default unit is pixels, and you can use the UNIT= dendrogram-option to change the unit to inches or centimeters for this option. Inches equals pixels divided by 96, and centimeters equals inches times 2.54. HEIGHT=PROPORTION | NCL | VAREXP or H=P | N | V specifies the method for drawing the height of the dendrogram. HEIGHT=PROPORTION is the default. HEIGHT=PROPORTION specifies that the total proportion of variance explained by the clusters at the current level of the tree is used. HEIGHT=NCL specifies that the number of clusters is used. HEIGHT=VAREXP specifies that the total variance explained by the clusters at the current level of the tree is used. HORIZONTAL | VERTICAL specifies either a horizontal dendrogram with the objects on the vertical axis (HORIZONTAL) or a vertical dendrogram with the objects on the horizontal axis (VERTICAL). The default is HORIZONTAL. SETHEIGHT=height SH=height specifies the height of the dendrogram. By default, the height is based on the COMPUTEHEIGHT= option. The default unit is pixels, and you can use the UNIT= dendrogram-option to change the unit to inches or centimeters for this dendrogram-option. SETWIDTH=width SW=width specifies the width of the dendrogram. By default, the width is based on the COMPUTEWIDTH= option. The default unit is pixels, and you can use the UNIT= dendrogram-option to change the unit to inches or centimeters for this dendrogram-option. UNIT=PX | IN | CM specifies the unit (pixels, inches, or centimeters) for the SETHEIGHT=, SETWIDTH=, COMPUTEHEIGHT=, and COMPUTEWIDTH= dendrogram-options.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Suppresses all plots.

arguments.name: PROPORTION=
arguments.description: Specifies that when choosing a cluster to split, VARCLUS should choose the cluster with the smallest proportion of variation explained, provided that its proportion of variation explained is less than the PROPORTION= value.

arguments.name: RANDOM=
arguments.description: Specifies a positive integer as a starting value for use with REPLACE=RANDOM.

arguments.name: SHORT
arguments.description: Suppresses display of the cluster structure, scoring coefficient, and intercluster correlation matrices.

arguments.name: SIMPLE
arguments.description: Displays means and standard deviations.

arguments.name: SUMMARY
arguments.description: Suppresses all default displayed output except the final summary table.

arguments.name: TRACE
arguments.description: Displays the cluster to which each variable is assigned during the iterations.

arguments.name: VARDEF=
arguments.description: Specifies the divisor to be used in the calculation of variances and covariances. By default, VARDEF=DF.

arguments.name: DF
arguments.description: Degrees of freedom

arguments.name: N
arguments.description: Number of observations

arguments.name: WDF
arguments.description: Sum of weights minus 1

arguments.name: WEIGHT
arguments.description: Sum of weights

statements.name: BY
statements.description: Obtains separate analyses on observations in groups defined by the BY variables.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: Specifies that the observations are sorted in descending order by the variable that immediately follows the word DESCENDING in the BY statement.

arguments.name: NOTSORTED
arguments.description: Specifies that observations are not necessarily sorted in alphabetic or numeric order.

statements.name: FREQ
statements.description: If a variable in your data set represents the frequency of occurrence for the other values in the observation, include the variableâ€™s name in a FREQ statement. The procedure then treats the data set as if each observation appears n times, where n is the value of the FREQ variable for the observation

statements.name: PARTIAL
statements.description: If you want to base the clustering on partial correlations, list the variables to be partialed out in the PARTIAL statement.

statements.name: SEED
statements.description: The SEED statement specifies variables to be used as seeds to initialize the clusters. It is not necessary to use INITIAL=SEED if the SEED statement is present, but if any other INITIAL= option is specified, the SEED statement is ignored.

statements.name: VAR
statements.description: The VAR statement specifies the variables to be clustered. If you do not specify the VAR statement and do not specify TYPE=SSCP, all numeric variables not listed in other statements (except the SEED statement) are processed.

statements.name: WEIGHT
statements.description: If you want to specify relative weights for each observation in the input data set, place the weights in a variable in the data set and specify the name in a WEIGHT statement. This is often done when the variance associated with each observation is different and the values of the weight variable are proportional to the reciprocals of the variances.
